item.title: Abrego Garcia Ordered Freed, But Faces Re-Arrest by Immigration
item.description: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, the Maryland man who the Trump administration mistakenly deported to a prison in El Salvador, remains in legal limbo after defeating a bid by the government to keep him locked up on criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Hurtado

media:content.media:description: Katheryn Millwee holds a portrait of Kilmar Abrego Garcia outside the federal courthouse, Wednesday, June 25, 2025, in Nashville, Tenn. (AP Photo/George Walker IV)

item.title: US Allows Ethane Cargoes to Sail to China After Inventories Soar
item.description: The Trump administration has slightly eased recent export limits on a petroleum gas that’s used to make plastics — a shift that represents a modest pullback on curbs used as leverage in trade negotiations with China.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: Railroad tanker cars sit parked on the grounds of the Sunoco Logistics Marcus Hook Industrial Complex ethane terminal in Marcus Hook, Pennsylvania, U.S., on Friday, April 8, 2016. U.S. production of ethane, a key feedstock for petrochemical manufacturing, is expected to increase to 1.4 million barrels per day by 2017 as more facilities come online, according to Commodity Online. Photographer: Luke Sharrett/

item.title: Vance to Attend $250,000 Nantucket Dinner Hosted by Putnam CEO
item.description: Vice President JD Vance is scheduled to headline a political fundraiser in Nantucket in July, according to a person familiar with the matter, courting the Massachusetts island’s wealthy summer crowd to bolster Republicans before the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Cam Baker

media:content.media:description: US Vice President JD Vance during a swearing-in ceremony for Howard Lutnick, US commerce secretary, not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, Feb. 21, 2025. Lutnick, approved on a Senate vote of 51-45 on Tuesday, will oversee a large department with responsibilities ranging from fisheries management to export controls.

item.title: Early Report Suggests US Strikes Only Set Back Iran Nuclear Program by Months
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — A U.S. intelligence report suggests that Iran’s nuclear program has been set back only a few months after U.S. strikes and was not “completely and fully obliterated” as President Donald Trump has said, according to two people familiar with the early assessment.

media:content.media:description: Building damage across the Isfahan nuclear technology center in Iran on June 22.

item.title: Republicans ‘Far From’ Deal on SALT Limit, New Yorker Says
item.description: House Republicans from high-tax states remain at loggerheads with the Senate GOP over limits on the state and local tax deduction despite a meeting with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent to try to resolve differences, a New York lawmaker said.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Cam Kettles

media:content.media:description: Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent speaks to reporters in Washington, DC, on June 24.

item.title: Starmer Seeks to Expand Service Exports in UK Trade Strategy
item.description: The UK is seeking to increase the recognition of British professional certifications abroad, a move aimed at boosting the nation’s service-sector exports by making it easier for highly skilled employees to work for clients overseas.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, during a meeting with Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, at 10 Downing Street in London, UK, on Monday, June 23, 2025. Zelenskiy is ramping up Ukraine's defense industry.

item.title: Treasury’s Faulkender Sees Sub-April 2 Tariff Rates After Talks
item.description: Deputy Treasury Secretary Michael Faulkender said the expectation is that, following negotiations with US trading partners, tariffs won’t go back as high as the reciprocal levies that President Donald Trump announced on April 2.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Kailey Leinz, Joe Mathieu

media:content.media:description: Michael Faulkender, deputy US treasury secretary, during a Psaros Center for Financial Markets and Policy event at Georgetown University in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 6, 2025. Michelle Bowman, incoming vice chair for supervision at the US Federal Reserve, says the central bank will soon address the "odd mismatch" between the confidential ratings of big banks and the lenders' financial conditions.

item.title: US Accuses Three Mexican Financial Firms of Aiding Fentanyl Trafficking
item.description: The US government identified three Mexican financial firms for potentially laundering proceeds from illicit drug trafficking, effectively choking them off from the US financial system as it seeks to clamp down on cartels.
item.dc:creator: Michael O'Boyle

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC.

item.title: California Reaches $321 Billion Budget Deal Boosting Hollywood
item.description: California Governor Gavin Newsom and state lawmakers struck a budget agreement that provides $750 million in tax credits for Hollywood while scaling back free health care for undocumented immigrants.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher, Andrew Oxford

media:content.media:description: Gavin Newsom, governor of California, speaks during a news conference in Sacramento, California, U.S., on Tuesday, April 14, 2020. Newsom outlined his plan to lift restrictions in the most-populous U.S. state, saying a reopening depends on meeting a series of benchmarks that would remake daily life for 40 million residents.

item.title: Trump Says US-Iran Will Talk Next Week, Mideast War Over for Now
item.description: President Donald Trump said the US would hold a meeting with Iran next week but cast doubt on the need for a diplomatic agreement on the country’s nuclear program, citing the damage that American bombing had done to key sites.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Jennifer A Dlouhy, Annmarie Hordern

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference at the NATO summit in The Hague, on June 25.

item.title: Trump’s Tax Cut Bill Progress May Hinge on SALT Content
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, Capitol influence reporter Emily Birnbaum looks at the status of the Republican tax-cut and spending bill with a deadline coming up. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum

item.title: Mamdani’s Rent-Freeze Agenda Sparks Slide in NYC-Linked REITs
item.description: Shares of companies linked to New York City real estate fell Wednesday as Zohran Mamdani, a state Assembly member who has vowed to freeze rents, looks all but certain to become the Democratic nominee for mayor.
item.dc:creator: Norah Mulinda, Georgie McKay, Natalie Wong

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani, New York City mayoral candidate, during an election night event in New York, US, early on Wednesday, June 25, 2025. More than 930,000 New Yorkers cast their ballots in the city's Democratic primary, with more than half withstanding record temperatures to vote at polling stations on Tuesday.

item.title: Mamdani’s Shock Win Has Wall Street Fretting Over ‘Hot Commie Summer’
item.description: Even Zohran Mamdani’s detractors recognize that the vibes are with the 33-year-old democratic socialist.
item.dc:creator: Sridhar Natarajan, Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani during a campaign event in New York, on June 23.

item.title: MIT Sued by Student, Instructor Claiming Campus Antisemitism
item.description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology was sued by an instructor and a former student who claim the school’s administration failed to address a “hostile anti-Semitic environment” on campus following the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks in Israel by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators at an encampment at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Tuesday, April 23, 2024. Campuses across the US have been grappling with pro-Palestinian protests and counter demonstrations since the Oct. 7 attack on Israel by Hamas.

item.title: HUD Plans to Move Operations From Washington to Virginia
item.description: The US Department of Housing and Urban Development is relocating its headquarters to a federal building in Virginia, months after the agency’s existing space downtown in Washington was put up for sale as part of a broader effort by President Donald Trump’s administration to consolidate its real estate.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: The US Department of Housing and Urban Development headquarters in Washington, DC. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Slams NYC Mayoral Candidate Mamdani as ‘Communist Lunatic’
item.description: President Donald Trump described Zohran Mamdani, the expected Democratic nominee for New York City mayor, as a “Communist Lunatic,” signaling how Republicans will seek to portray the upstart politician as representative of the party.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani during an election night event in New York, on June 25.

item.title: California Schools Risk DC Funding Cuts on Transgender Athlete Debate
item.description: Public school funding in California is at risk after the US Education Department found that the state is violating rules protecting female athletes from unfair competition and unsafe situations “by allowing males in girls’ sports and intimate spaces.”
item.dc:creator: Erin Hudson

item.title: Trump Threatens to Double Spanish Tariffs Over NATO Spending
item.description: President Donald Trump assailed Spain for refusing to agree to new defense spending targets adopted by NATO and suggested the country could be penalized by facing tariffs twice as high from the US.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Josh Wingrove

item.title: Petro Bickers With Lawyers for Colombian Senator Shot in Head
item.description: A legal battle has erupted over the attempted assassination of a Colombian presidential candidate, with the nation’s incumbent leftist leader accusing lawyers for the hospitalized conservative senator of slander.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Petro speaks in Medellin, Colombia, on June 21. Photographer: Edinson Arroyo/Bloomberg

item.title: Clashes Between Kenya Police, Protesters Leave Eight Dead
item.description: Eight people were reported to have died in clashes between the Kenyan police and protesters, who gathered to mark the first anniversary of deadly anti-government demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: A man waves a Kenyan flag as demonstrators march in downtown Nairobi on June 25. Photographer: LUIS TATO/AFP

item.title: Can the World Count on ‘TACO’ Anymore?
item.description: In this episode of Trumponomics, we explore whether Donald Trump’s attack on Iran changes the calculus on his “reciprocal” tariffs and a looming deadline.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump looks up at the new flagpole on the South Lawn of the White House after arriving on Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, June 21, 2025. Trump often suggests that something will happen in "two weeks" when he's looking to buy himself some time. But his latest two-weeks declaration — on possible US military strikes in Iran — comes with unusually high stakes.

item.title: NJ Congresswoman Pleads Not Guilty to Obstructing ICE Agents
item.description: US Representative LaMonica McIver pleaded not guilty to federal charges that she interfered with law enforcement outside a 1,000-bed immigration detention facility in Newark, New Jersey.
item.dc:creator: Chris Dolmetsch

media:content.media:description: LaMonica McIver exits the grounds at Delaney Hall, an ICE detention facility, in Newark, New Jersey, on May 9.

item.title: Royal Pomp and Political Flattery Help Sway Trump on NATO Unity
item.description: It was a reception fit for a king.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Flavia Krause-Jackson, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Trump arrives for a state dinner hosted by the Dutch royal family.

item.title: Trump Says US to Consider More Air-Defense Batteries for Ukraine
item.description: Donald Trump said he will look into sending more Patriot air-defense batteries to Ukraine following “a good” meeting with President Volodymyr Zelenskiy as allies seek more US pressure on Russia to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Andrea Dudik

media:content.media:description: Volodymyr Zelenskiy, left, and Donald Trump in The Hague, on June 25. Source: Ukrainian Presidential Press Office

item.title: How Trump’s Spurning of European Allies Is Transforming NATO
item.description: NATO is trying to reinvent itself just as the military alliance confronts Europe’s deadliest conflict since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Kati Pohjanpalo

media:content.media:description: US President Trump at the 2018 NATO Summit. Photographer: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

item.title: Alberta Premier Warns Carney He Must Act to Quell Separatist Threat
item.description: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith played down concerns that the secession movement in her province will scare away investors, saying it’s up to the government of Mark Carney to prove Canada can be a more attractive place for capital.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Orland

media:content.media:description: Danielle Smith, Alberta's premier, during an interview in Calgary, Alberta, Canada, on Monday, June 23, 2025. Smith expects a private-sector firm to propose a new oil pipeline to the British Columbia coast within weeks in a bid to become one of the first entrants on the Canadian government's list of nationally important projects.

item.title: AI Titans Flex Clout to Leverage Tax Bill to Override State Laws
item.description: Powerful Silicon Valley leaders are throwing their weight behind the tech industry’s drive to use Donald Trump’s tax bill to sweep away state regulations on artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Oma Seddiq

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, June 23, 2025. President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending agenda is nearing a climactic vote in the Senate this week in the wake of air strikes on Iran, which risk embroiling the US in a prolonged Middle East conflict.

item.title: Carney Says Canada Met With European Suppliers Amid F-35 Review
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said he met with European defense suppliers about jets and submarines, and expects to conclude a review of a major contract for Lockheed Martin Corp. F-35 jets as soon as this summer.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: Canada's prime minister Mark Carney speaks during a news conference at the NATO summit in The Hague, on June 25.

item.title: Dutch Far-Right Leader Courts President Trump at NATO Summit
item.description: Dutch far-right leader Geert Wilders met with Donald Trump on the sidelines of the NATO Summit in The Hague, where they discussed “the need for tougher immigration laws,” Wilders said in a post on X.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Hughes-Morgan, Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: Geert Wilders

item.title: Middle East War Reset Dollar’s Inverse Link to Stocks, Goldman Says
item.description: This month’s geopolitical tension focused on the Middle East is re-establishing the dollar’s traditional inverse relationship with risk assets, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc.
item.dc:creator: Carter Johnson
